Posted April 1, 2007

DeGrave, Jean Marion

Jean Marion DeGrave, 81, Green Bay, died Friday, March 30, 2007, at a local nursing home following a lengthy illness. She was born April 29, 1925, in Green Bay to Charles and Helen (O'Grady) Spargo. Jean was a graduate of Green Bay East High School. She enjoyed watching sports on television. Jean was an avid Packers fan and loved watching Tiger Woods play golf. She was a devoted mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother.

Jean is survived by her two daughters and a son-in-law, Barb and David Krajnik, Sr., Debra Besaw and her special friend, Andy Anderson; her three grandchildren and their spouses, Sean (Taunya) Krajnik, David Krajnik, Jr., and Carrie (Danny) Oakley; her four great-grandchildren, Baile, Peyton, Riley, Zaine, and a soon to be "Baby Oakley"; her two sisters, Betty Rybicki and June Burch; her nieces and nephews, Michael Burch, Mary Rybicki, Patrice (Mike) Welsing, Ronald (Kris) Burch, and other relatives and friends.

She was preceded in death by her parents, her children's father, Richard DeGrave; her brothers-in-law, William Burch and Clement Rybicki; and her nephew, Charles Rybicki.

Friends may call at St. Jude Catholic Church, 1420 Division Street, on Wednesday from 10 a.m. to 11 a.m. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated at 11 a.m. Wednesday at the church with the Rev. Peter Renard O. Praem officiating. Blaney Funeral Home is assisting the family. To send online condolences, please go to www.blaneyfuneralhome.com.

Jean's family wishes to thank the staff of Grancare Nursing Center for the care they showed to our mother.

Posted April 1, 2007

Pagels, Raymond W.

Raymond W. Pagels, 86, of 726 South 35th Street, Manitowoc, entered eternal life peacefully Friday evening, March 30, 2007, at Bellin Health Hospital Center, Green Bay. Ray was born March 2, 1921, in Merrill, Wis. He was the son of the late Benhard and Bertha Harbath Pagels. He attended Merrill High School graduating with the class of 1939. He then entered the United States Army in 1946 and served overseas during World War II in the Philippines and New Guinea. After being honorably discharged in 1948, Ray was employed with Sears as an advertising and display manager for 37 years retiring in 1984. On Jan. 16, 1943, he married Mae Taddy at St. Luke's Catholic Church Rectory in Two Rivers. She preceded him in death on Sept. 24, 2006. Ray, along with his loving and caring wife Mae, enjoyed many, many wonderful years at their north woods cabin.

He is survived by his two sons and daughters-in-law, Jeffrey and Jane Pagels, Ashwaubenon, Wis.; Brad and Krystal Pagels, Eagle River, Wis.; daughter and son-in-law, Jennifer and John DeFranco, North Prairie, Wis.; a sister-in-law; six grandchildren; three great-grandchildren; nieces, nephews along with other relatives and friends surviving.

He was preceded in death by his wife, Mae, in 2006; one son, Gregg, in 1981; and 5 brothers.

Memorial services will be held 11 a.m. Monday, April 2, 2007, at the Harrigan Parkside Funeral Home and Cremation Center. Cremation will have taken place with burial of the cremains to be at Evergreen Cemetery, Manitowoc. Relatives and friends may call at the Funeral Home on Monday, April 2, 2007, from 10 a.m. until the time of services at 11 a.m.

The family would appreciate in lieu of flowers memorials for the Lakeshore Visually Impaired Support Group. Job 19:25-26 For I know my redeemer liveth and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the earth ... yet in my flesh I shall see God. The Harrigan Parkside Funeral Home and Cremation Center, North 11th and St. Clare Streets, Manitowoc, is assisting the family with funeral arrangements.

Posted April 1, 2007

Sacotte, Francis

Francis Sacotte, 77, Casco, died Friday March 30, 2007. He was born April 4, 1929, in the Town of Red River to the late Frank and Clara (DeCramer) Sacotte. He married Joan Vandermause on Sept. 29, 1948. Francis farmed along with his wife in the Town of Casco for 41 years. He was also employed at Kewaunee Engineering for 38 years. Francis was an avid fisherman and a loving husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He enjoyed life to the fullest.

He is survived by his loving wife, Joan; his children, Nancy (Ken) Boucher, Anita (Mark) Mueller, Peggy (Larry) Johnson, Maria (Dan) Rueckl and Paul (Anne) Sacotte; grandchildren, Jenny (Rob) Kinnard, Sarah (Jamie) Conard, Alison (Jesse) Schley, Jessica, Adam, Andrew (Stephanie) Mueller, Carrie (Ken) Seymour, Angie (Kevin) Neal, Valerie (Joe) Delebreau, Brian (fiance Stacy) Rueckl, Ryan, Kaitlyn and Steven Sacotte; great-grandchildren, Trevor and Carson Kinnard, Selina and Sophie Conard, Braeden Schley, Adelynn, Brielle and Cadence Seymour, Isaiah Neal and Caleb Delebreau; one brother, Larry (Bettie) Sacotte; brothers-in-law, and sisters-in-law, Ethel Wautier, Orville (Flo), Ervin (Shirley) and Richard (Gloria) Vandermause, Erna (Wallace) Vandenhouten and Melvin DeJardin.

Francis was preceded in death by one son, Steven; one great-grandaughter, Lindsay Conard; and one infant sister.

Friends may call at Wiesner-Massart Funeral Home, Casco, from 4 to 8 p.m. Monday and again Tuesday morning at the funeral home until 10:15 a.m. Wake service at 6 p.m. Monday. Funeral Tuesday 10:30 a.m. at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, Casco with Fr. Milton Suess officiating. Entombment in Shrine of Good Sherherd Mausoleum.

Posted April 1, 2007

Vanderveren, Richard Henry

Richard Henry Vanderveren, 82, Flintville, died Wednesday, March 28, 2007. He was born Dec. 8, 1924, to Clarence and Genevieve (Caelwaerts) Vanderveren. Richard had farmed in the Suamico area all of his life. He loved everything outdoors, hunting, fishing, cutting wood and enjoyed his bear hunting group. He also enjoyed being with his family.

Survivors include two brothers and one sister-in-law, Dale Vanderveren and his friend, Bonnie, Suamico; Carl and Mary Vanderveren, Townsend; nieces and nephews, including two godchildren, Luke (Christine) Vanderveren, Craig Vanderveren, Cindy (John) Hynes, Leanne (Dave) Tomaschefsky, Vanessa (Mike) Marin, Mark Vanderveren and his friend, Michelle, Chris (Bill) Andrews, Sally Vanderveren and her friend, Gary, Lance (Becky) Vanderveren, Earl Vanderveren; many great-nieces and great-nephews.

He was preceded in death by his sister-in-law, Mrs. Dale (Evelyn) Vanderveren.

Friends may call at Blaney Funeral Home, 1521 Shawano Ave., from 5 to 7 p.m. Sunday. Friends may also call at Ss. Edward & Isidore Catholic Church, 3667 Flintville Rd., Flintville, from 10 to 11 a.m. Monday. The Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 a.m. Monday at the church with the Rev. David Kasperek officiating. Burial will be in St. John the Baptist Cemetery. To send online condolences, please go to www.BlaneyFuneralHome.com.

4/1/2007 Herald Times Reporter

Green Bay.

4/2/2007 GBPG

Posted April 2, 2007

Geurts, Erma E.

Erma E. Geurts, 84, De Pere, passed away peacefully surrounded by her family March 31, 2007. The daughter of Michael and Odelia (Liebergen) Heim was born June 12, 1922, in Green Bay. Erma married Arthur Geurts on Sept. 6, 1941, at St. Phillip Catholic Church in Green Bay. He preceded her in death July 7, 1999. Art and Erma owned and operated Geurts' Bar in De Pere for over 30 years. Erma enjoyed couples bowling with Art for many years. She was a member of St. Mary Catholic Community. Erma was a person of faith and prayed daily for her family and friends. She was an avid Packers and NASCAR fan.

Erma is survived by her children, Sharon (Ken) Peters, Sandy (Marvin) Clarksen, Mike (Louise) Geurts, Linda (Tim) Robertson, Kelly (Donna) Geurts, all De Pere; Rick (Sherri) Geurts, Greenleaf; Scott (Mary) Geurts, Seymour; Jeff (Debbie) Geurts, Perry (Lynn) Geurts, both De Pere; her grandchildren, Todd Peters and his friend, Jane, Eric (Missy) Peters, Bruce (Lori) Clarksen, Brian (Chris) Clarksen, Kevin Clarksen, Cathy Clarksen, Matt (Carrie) Clarksen, Doug Geurts, Michelle (Todd) West, Shannon (Scott) Luscher, Tara (Jason) Wegner, Jason Geurts, Josh Geurts, Kendall Leigh Geurts, Colten Geurts, Katrina Geurts, Cameron Geurts; 9 great-grandchildren, Ella and Tessa Peters, Nicholas, Courtney, Brianna and Connor Clarksen, Evan Gilbert, Jacob and Jeremy West; brother and sisters, Lorraine Geurts and Alice Danielski, both Green Bay; and Leo (Arlene) Heim, Denmark; sisters-in-law, Loretta La Court, Luxemburg; and LaVerne Geurts, De Pere; numerous nieces and nephews.

She was preceded in death by her parents; her husband, Art; great-grandson, Cory Partrick Clarksen; her sisters and brothers, Alma (Henry) Baye, Evelyn (Nick) Sasman, Loretta (Leslie) Connelly, Clarence (Josephine) Heim, Richard (Margaret) Heim, Gordon (Tillie) Heim and her twin brother, Urban (Bernice) Heim.

Friends may call from 4 to 8 p.m. Monday (TODAY) at Cotter Funeral Home, 860 N Webster Avenue, De Pere. Parish Prayer Service 7 p.m. at the funeral home. Visitation will continue from 10 to 11 a.m. Tuesday at St. Mary Catholic Community, Pope John XXIII Circle, off Sportsman Drive, Town of Ledgeview. Mass of Christian Burial 11 a.m. Tuesday at the church with the Rev. John H. Harper officiating. Entombment in Allouez Chapel Mausoleum. A memorial fund has been established in Erma's name. Online condolences may be expressed to the family at www.cotterfuneralhome.com.

Erma's family extends a special thank you to the entire staff of the 9th floor at St. Vincent Hospital as well as the staff at Woodside Manor III for all of their care and concern.

4/2/2007 Post Crescent

Posted April 2, 2007

Jost, Boyd

Boyd Jost, Neenah, 77, passed away after a courageous battle with cancer on Saturday, March 31, 2007, with his family by his side at Cherry Meadows Hospice. He was born June 11, 1929, in Neenah, son of the late Mathias and Josephine (Kirchmeyer) Jost. Boyd served with the 11th Airborne during the Korean Conflict. He married Peggy Moss on Feb. 7, 1959, and they enjoyed 48 wonderful years together. Boyd was employed by CW Transport for 30 years where he logged over two million accident free miles. He enjoyed his grandchildren, hunting, fishing, camping and his rose garden. Boyd also enjoyed swapping stories and he could enter a room full of strangers and leave with a room full of friends.

Survivors include his wife, Peggy; a son, Gregory (Laura) Jost; a daughter, Kristine (Russell) Eriksen-Crane; eight grandchildren, Shannon (Collin) Baulch, Jeremy, Jennifer, Hannah and Nicholas Jost, Daniel, Andrew and Lissi Eriksen; two step-grandchildren, Brandon and Tyler Crane; a sister-in-law, Gertrude (Joseph) Jost. Boyd is further survived by numerous nieces and nephews.

He was preceded in death by four brothers, Joseph, James, Leon and Mathias; and three sisters, Marie, Eva and Eunice.

The Mass of Resurrection will be held at 11:30 a.m. on Tuesday, April 3, 2007, at St. Gabriel Catholic Church in Neenah with Fr. Richard Allen officiating. Family and friends will be received at the church from 9:30 a.m. until the time of services. Memories will be shared following the service. Military rites will be preformed by the American Legion Kimberly Post #60. In lieu of flowers, a memorial has been set up for cancer patient care with ThedaCare at Home Hospice.

Gone from our sight but never from our hearts. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him.

The family would like to thank Theda Care at Home Hospice for all the loving care and concern given to Boyd and his family.

WESTGOR FUNERAL HOME

205 W. Doty Ave.

Neenah 920-722-7151

4/2/2007 Herald Times Reporter

Posted April 2, 2007

Deanne DeLarwell

Deanne DeLarwell, age 69, a resident of River's Bend Health & Rehabilitation Center, Manitowoc, died Thursday, March 1, 2007, at Aurora Medical Center, Two Rivers.

Deanne was born May 6, 1937, in Two Rivers, son of the late Albert and Helen (Majeski) Duckett.

Survivors include a son, Mark DeLarwell, and a sister, Marian Delisle, both of Lake Geneva. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by a brother, James Duckett, and a sister, Angie Hoffman, both of Manitowoc.

The family will greet relatives and friends from 4 to 6 p.m. on Wednesday, April 4, 2007, at the Klein & Stangel Funeral Home and Cremation Care Center, Two Rivers. Cremation has taken place and there will be no funeral service.

Herald Times Reporter

April 2, 2007

Posted April 2, 2007

Patrick L. O'Neill

Patrick L. O'Neill, age 55, of 3805 Tannery Road, Two Rivers, passed away Saturday, March 31, 2007, at Aurora Medical Center, Two Rivers.

Patrick was born July 5, 1951, in Wausau, Wis., son of Lyman and Fern (Chrudimsky) O'Neill. He graduated from Antigo High School, Class of 1969. On May 5, 1973, he married the former Crystal L. De Bauch at Good Shepherd Lutheran Church, Two Rivers.

Patrick was a longtime employee of Mirro. He enjoyed hunting, fishing and restoring old cars. Patrick was also a lifetime member of the West Shore Gun Club. The last three years he was very involved with Kids N Us daycare.

Survivors include his loving wife, Crystal O'Neill, Two Rivers; one daughter, Tracy L. O'Neill, Mt. Calvary, Wis.; one son and daughter-in-law, Timothy P.L. and Melissa O'Neill, Milwaukee; his parents, Lyman and Fern O'Neill, Aniwa, Wis.; one sister and brother-in-law, Darlene and Mark Capes, Neillsville, Wis.; and three brothers and sisters-in-law, Jerome and Roxanne O'Neill, Kaukauna; William and Carol O'Neill, Aniwa, Wis.; James and Mary O'Neill, Aniwa, Wis. He is further survived by nieces, nephews, friends and all the children that he loved and who enriched his life at Kids N Us daycare.

Patrick was preceded in death by his maternal grandparents, Edward and Ester Chrudimsky, paternal grandparents, George and Ella O'Neill, and his father-in-law and mother-in-law, Lawrence and Mabel De Bauch.

Services will be held at 11 a.m. on Wednesday, April 4, 2007, at Good Shepherd Lutheran Church, Two Rivers. Officiating at the service will be the Rev. William Kilps with burial to be in Knollwood Memorial Park Cemetery, Highways B and 310.

The family will greet relatives and friends from 10 a.m. Wednesday until the time of service at 11 a.m. at the church.

The Klein & Stangel Funeral Home, Two Rivers, is assisting the O'Neill family with funeral arrangements.

Herald Times Reporter

April 2, 2007

Posted April 2, 2007

Stanley E. Spevacek

Stanley E. Spevacek, 89, Green Bay, formerly of Maribel, passed away suddenly Saturday evening, March 31, 2007, at a Green Bay hospital.

Born Oct. 26, 1917, in Maribel, he was the son of the late John and Anna (Straka) Spevacek. Stanley married Hazel Willmite on Aug. 24, 1940. Together, the couple worked the family farm near Melnik in northern Manitowoc County for many years. In later years, Stanley was employed by Burger Boat Company, retiring in 1980. The couple moved to Green Bay in 2005 to be near their family. He was a current member of Messiah Ev. Lutheran Church in Green Bay. Stanley was an avid lover of polka music and woodcarving.

He is survived by his wife of nearly 67 years, Hazel; four sons and their spouses, Kirby of White River, Ariz., Glenn and Kathy of Green Bay, Dennis and Debbie of Bellevue, and Randall Spevacek of Green Bay; nine grandchildren; 17 great grandchildren; a sister: Evelyn Shimanek of Green Bay.

He was preceded in death by his parents; an infant daughter, Geraldine; daughter-in-law: Audrey Spevacek; brother-in-law, Ed Shimanek.

Friends may call at Messiah Ev. Lutheran Church, 3186 Eaton Road, Green Bay, Thursday, April 5, from 10:30 a.m. until the time of the memorial service at 11 a.m. with the Rev. Stephen Sauer officiating.

In lieu of other expressions of sympathy, donations in Stanley's name may be directed to Messiah Lutheran Building Fund.

Please visit malcorefuneral home.com to send online condolences to the family.

Herald Times Reporter

April 2, 2007

4/3/2007 GBPG

Posted April 3, 2007

Johnson, Gloria Dawn

Gloria Dawn Johnson (nee Kralapp), was born May 20, 1935, in the town of Pensaukee, Wis., to Henry and Evelyn Kralapp.

Gloria, whose deep faith in God sustained her through her courageous battle with cancer, passed to the Lord on Saturday, March 31, 2007.

Gloria's life was rich as an educator, a volunteer, a mother and wife, and as a servant to our Lord. Gloria's childhood was spent in Oconto Falls, Wis., where she attended school. Her graduate and post-graduate schooling was at the University of Wisconsin-Oshkosh where she obtained her master's degree in education. Gloria moved to Appleton where she taught fifth- and sixth-graders for 28 years at Lincoln Elementary and Houdini Elementary schools.

Gloria served as one of the founding presidents of the Winnegamie Dog Club with a deep love of all animals. She was president of the Fox Valley Reading Council, and passed on her love of reading to her family and many students. She also worked as a volunteer for the Children's Museum and the Appleton Education Foundation. Her beautiful voice was heard at the Fox Valley Symphony Chorus as well as her church, First English Lutheran, where she served as a council member, a teacher and aide, and in many Bible studies.

Gloria was an inspiration throughout her life with a zeal for her family, her travels, and the outdoors. She traveled with the Appleton Boy Choir on their first tour to Russia and Poland. She and her husband sailed with the Oshkosh Yacht Club and skied with the Ventures Ski Club. And she helped guide her children in their many camping trips throughout the country.

Gloria is survived by a loving husband of 52 years, Willis (Bill); her son, Bruce (spouse, Connie and children, Tyler, Lauren and Ben; her son-in-law, Michael McKenzie (friend, Stephanie and his children, Conor, Kelsey, and Morgan); her son, Scott (children, Dayleen and Cassandra); brothers, Gary (spouse, Carol and family) and Glen (spouse, Mary Kay and family); along with many nieces, nephews and students that she has taught through the years.

She is preceded in death by her parents, her sister, Joyce, her brothers, Merle and Ralph, and her daughter, Deborah.

Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. Friday, April 6, 2007, at First English Lutheran Church with Rev. George Detweiler officiating. Visitation will be from 9 a.m. until the time of service Friday at the church. Entombment will be in Highland Memorial Park, Appleton.

In lieu of flowers, a memorial fund has been established for the Appleton Education Foundation.

Gloria would also like to thank all the "girls" who were so thoughtful and caring through her battle with cancer, her neighbors, the teachers she has worked with through the years, the staff at Cherry Meadows and her church groups.

Valley Funeral Home

Posted April 3, 2007

Knaus, Francis Austin "Fran"

Francis Austin "Fran" Knaus, 75, Ashwaubenon, passed away on March 30, 2007, after a short battle with cancer with his family at his side.

Francis was born on April 11, 1931, in Green Bay, to the late Frederick and Etta (Bentley) Knaus. He was a 1949 graduate of West High School in Green Bay and served his country as a member of the U.S. Navy.

On July 7, 1956, he married the former Sally Biemeret at St. Francis Xavier Cathedral.

He was employed with Fort Howard Paper for 36 years until he retired in 1991. He also worked at Glen's Gas and Oil in Green Bay for more than 40 years. Francis loved baseball. In his younger years he played baseball and in his later years he enjoyed watching baseball. He also enjoyed bowling and fishing.

He will be sadly missed by his wife of 50 years, Sally Knaus; three children, Brian (Beverly) Knaus, Jacksonville, Fla.; Denise (T.J. Miller) Vanderperren, Green Bay; and Erin (Raphael) Clark, Sobieski; six grandchildren, Greg Knaus, Jacksonville; Natalie (Anthony) Juline, Green Bay; Heather (fiance, Lucas Phillips) Vanderperren, Green Bay; Faith Knaus, Jacksonville; Garrett Clark; and Garrison Clark, Sobieski. He is also survived by three brothers, Fred, Merle and Allen "Luke"; five sisters, Gertrude, Leone, Ethlyn, Kaye and Beverly; as well as many other relatives and friends.

He was preceded in death by his parents; Sally's parents Gabriel and Ione Biemeret; three brothers, Dale, Lloyd and Connie; one sister, Loretta and infant sister, Joyce.

At Fran's request, private services were held. Proko-Wall Funeral Home and Crematory is assisting the family. Online condolences may be expressed at www.prokowall.com.

The family would like to express a very special thank you to two of Francis' nephews, Larry and Robert Biemeret. All your help, care and concern are greatly appreciated. Also thank you to the staff and nurses of Heartland Hospice.

Posted April 3, 2007

Massey, Vicki Lynn (Erickson)

Vicki Lynn Massey (Erickson), 57, died unexpectedly at home March 30, 2007.

She was born Feb. 22, 1950, in Rhinelander, Wis., the third daughter of Donald James Erickson and Hazel Lorraine "Babe" Palmer Erickson.

Vicki grew to young womanhood "up north" in the "Kentuck" country or Argonne and Crandon, Wis. The family moved to Green Bay in 1965 where she met the love of her life, Gary J. Massey, who, in a burst of good judgment, married her on April 5, 1967, in Hinsdale, Ill. The blooming of their love gave life to their children, Staci Lynn and Gary John "G.J." Jr.

Vicki's survivors include her husband, Gary J. Massey; her daughter, Dr. Staci Simonich, Ph.D., and son-in-law, Dr. Michael Simonich, Ph.D.; her grandchildren, Noah Simonich, age 3, and his little sister, Grace Simonich, age 1; her sister, Sandi Erickson Carter and her brother-in-law, Bobby Carter and their children; her sister, Jackie Erickson Shepherd and brother-in-law, Bob Shepherd and their children; her sister-in-law, De Anne Massey; and her brother-in-law, Ronald Massey.

Vicki was greeted at heaven's gate by her parents; mother-in-law and father-in-law, Daryl and John Massey; her beloved son, Gary Massey Jr. who walked her through the reception line.

Married for 40 years, Vicki lived and loved with a great big heart, working overtime on every task. Every element of daily existence got her full bore treatment: Mom extraordinaire, gourmet chef, flower queen, magnificent listener and constant caregiver. Vicki did not escape the brutal episodes that fate deals to most of us. She buckled, she failed at times, she never quit. The untimely death of her son, G.J., almost did her in but she once again drew on that invincible will; that indomitable spirit to survive.

Nobody lives forever. Every soul does. Vicki's immediate family and closer friends will gather at MALCORE Funeral Home, University Avenue, at Baird Street, Green Bay, Thursday, April 5, 2007 (Gary and Vicki's 40th Wedding Anniversary), from 3 p.m. until 7 p.m. to ponder, to converse, to wonder, to help each get through the great change. After cremation, Vicki's ashes will unite with the land she loved so much. Her spirit will continue with each of us, still caring, still cared for. To express an online condolence please visit malcorefuneralhome.com.

Kenneth J. Pirlot, 82, Green Bay, died Monday, April 2, 2007, at a local nursing home.

Posted April 3, 2007

Szczepanski, Mildred

Our loving mother, Mildred Szczepanski, 88, reached her heavenly home on Palm Sunday, April 1, 2007. She resided with her daughter, Sandra Parks, and was under the care of LeRoyer Hospice of Antigo.

She was born on May 9, 1918, in De Pere, to the late Oliver and Arabel (Briscol) Brunette. On April 20, 1938, she married the love of her life, Chester Szczepanski and he preceded in death in 1963.

Mildred is survived by her nine children, Pat (Wayne) Spakowitz, Joyce (Woodford) Neff, David (Mary Jo) Szczepanski, Sandra Parks, Ken (Diane) Szczepanski, Mark (Connie) Szczepanski, Jim (Lynn) Szczepanski, Mike (Cathy) Szczepanski, Mary (Jim) Rechner; 15 grandchildren, Brad Spakowitz and Cherryl Zastrow, Bob, Bill, Greg Szczepanski, Ed and Craig Parks, Tami VanGruensven, Chad Szczepanski, Jeff, Nicole, Krista Szczepanski, Jim Szczepanski Jr., Steven Rechner, Frank Jones; 12 great-grandchildren; brothers, Melvin (Marge) Brunette, Norbert (Loretta) Brunette, Gerald Brunette; brothers-in-law, John Scepanski, Victor Peters, godchild, Darold LaBlanc; many nieces, nephews and friends.

She was preceded in death by her husband; parents; grandchildren, Brian Woodford, Maire Mildred Szczepanski, Jennifer Jan Szczepanski; great-grandchild, Alyssa Woodford; sisters, Ruth (Albert) LaBlanc, Mae (John) VerHagen; brothers, Joseph (Carol) Brunette, Walter (Mary) Brunette, Milton (Cora Lyn) Brunette; brothers-in-law, Joe (Helen) Szcepanski, Stanley (Patsy) Nowaczyk; sisters-in-law, Katherine Peters, Alice Scepanski; sons-in-law, Earl Woodford, Gordon Neff, Earl Parks; daughter-in-law, Linda Szczepanski.

Family and friends may call at the Pfotenhauer Funeral Home & Cremation Service, Howard-Suamico location, 1145 Cardinal Lane, on Wednesday, April 4 from 4 until 8 p.m. Prayer service at 7:30 p.m. Visitation will continue on Thursday from 10 until 11. Funeral Service 11 a.m. Thursday at the funeral home with Father David Kasperek officiating. Burial in Suamico Cemetery. On-line condolences welcome at www.PfotenhauerFuneralHome.com.

PFOTENHAUER

Posted April 3, 2007

Mildred E. Demuth

Mildred E. Demuth, age 98, a resident of St. Mary's Home, died early Monday morning, April 2, 2007, at the home.

Funeral services will be held at 11 a.m. on Tuesday, April 10, 2007, at St. Francis of Assisi on Grand Avenue. Officiating at the Mass of Christian Burial will be Father Paul Demuth. Burial will occur at Calvary Cemetery, Manitowoc.

The family will greet relatives and friends from 4 until 7 p.m. on Monday April 9, 2007, at The Pfeffer Funeral Home, where a prayer service will conclude the visitation at 7 p.m. led by Father Paul Demuth. The visitation will continue on Tuesday, April 10, 2007, at St. Francis of Assisi on Grand Avenue from 10 a.m. until the time of service at 11 a.m.

Complete funeral arrangements will be announced by The Pfeffer Funeral Home, Manitowoc.

Herald Times Reporter

April 3, 2007

4/3/2007 Post Crescent

Posted April 3, 2007

Gorrell, Loretta Marie (Kercher)

Loretta Gorrell, 78, Neenah, died Sunday, April 1, 2007, following a short illness at Cherry Meadows Hospice. She was born August 21, 1928, in Oshkosh, daughter of Alfred and Louisa Kercher. Loretta married Fred Gorrell in May 1951 and he preceded her in death in 1973. She lived in Oshkosh before moving to Neenah. Loretta worked at Oshkosh B'Gosh and later at Kimberly-Clark Corporation in food service for 19 years. She loved to travel with her sister Ruth and other friends, loved cats and just recently lost her beloved cat, companion, Casey. She liked to play bingo, doing puzzles, a beer or old fashion now and then, Friday night fish fries and her mornings with the McDonald's "gang." She enjoyed being with all her friends at Fireside Commons, was a longtime member of Neenah Eagles Auxiliary. She greatly enjoyed her family, especially the grandkids.

St. John, Wilbert Charles Louis

Wilbert Charles Louis St. John, Appleton, passed into his Heavenly Home on March 30, 2007, suddenly and very unexpectedly of natural causes. His life's journey began in a one-room log cabin near Big Falls, Wisconsin. His loving parents were Harvey St. John and Sophie Conradt St. John. In 1940, Bert married the lovely Evelyn Hampel St. John and they had almost 65 extraordinary years together! Evelyn passed away on February 10, 2005. He was also preceded by his brothers: Earl (Battle of the Bulge, 1944) and Orville (1996).

After Bert's military service as a flight instructor during WWII, he had two very devoted daughters: Cheryl Hecker (Green Bay, WI) and Karen St. John (Stillwater, MN). Bert enjoyed his two sons-in-law: Wally Hecker and the late Robert Gobrick who he missed these last eight years. He is survived by his sister, Ruth Heller (Lewistown, MT) and two sisters-in-law: Lilly St. John (Lewiston, MT) and Ada Larson (Menasha, WI); two grandchildren: Robert Hecker (wife Susan) and Elizabeth Hecker; and several nieces and a nephew.

He loved flying and spent 24 years in the Air Force Reserve, retiring as a Lt. Colonel. He worked 38 years for the Wisconsin Telephone Company in the engineering division. In addition to devoting his life to his family, he had been active with the Elks Club, his McDonald's Morning Financial Friends, endless cottage projects, and extensive travel. He recently established a long-lasting scholarship program at Shiocton High School. He was an unusually active 91 years old, snowmobiling for hours this winter and doing carpentry projects.

He was a wonderful husband and the absolute best father ever! He was a solid rock for the entire family. We will forever love him with all our hearts and we so wanted him to be with us so much longer. We will dearly miss this giant of a man, who freely gave so much to those he knew! May God Bless him eternally!!

Friends may join the family at 4 p.m. before the Appleton Elks memorial tribute at 4:45 p.m. and the services at 5:00 p.m. on Wednesday, April 4 at Brettschneider-Trettin-Lederer Funeral Home, 606 N. Oneida St., Appleton. Pastor Brinkman of Faith Lutheran Church will officiate followed by military honors. In lieu of flowers, the family is sponsoring a research fund for peripheral neuropathy, a painful condition that Bert endured for years.

LaForce, Joseph F. Green Bay Business Leader

Joseph LaForce, one of the area's most prominent business executives, died at home on March 29 in Palm City, Fla. He was 84 years old. His wife and three children were at his side.

LaForce was born in Minonk, Ill., in 1922, the son of Joseph and Beatrice LaForce. He was raised in Upper Michigan and when the family moved to Green Bay, LaForce attended East High School. After graduating, he attended St. Norbert's College for a semester. His college work was interrupted by military service. After the service, LaForce continued his studies at The University of Wisconsin in Madison, where he met his wife, the former Eleanor "Mac" McBride of Chicago, Illinois. After the couple graduated, they were married in 1947.

Following Joe LaForce's brief stint in construction in Miami, the couple moved to Green Bay, where he began a residential building business, sometimes working alongside his father. In 1954, LaForce founded LaForce Builders Hardware to supply door hardware to builders. With two employees, he opened the company's first office in the basement of a building on Washington Street. Operating above the business at the time was the Green Bay Packers ticket office.

Today the company is one of the country's largest distributors of commercial doors and hardware as well as being a manufacturer of steel doors and frames with six offices throughout the Midwest. The company is headquartered on West Mason Street.

LaForce was a long-standing supporter of a range of Wisconsin- and Florida-based organizations with a consistent focus on education. LaForce had diverse interests beyond business. He was an enthusiastic world traveler. In his 80s, LaForce and his family made a tour of the Panama Canal, which had been a longtime interest for him and his wife. Both enjoyed classical music and they held season tickets to the Metropolitan Opera in New York. They were also patrons of the Green Bay Symphony.

He was a sports enthusiast, a skier and tennis player. His great passion was golf, and he spent many happy hours on the links at both Oneida Country Club in Green Bay and Harbor Ridge Country Club in Stuart, Fla.

Besides his wife, Mac, LaForce is survived by three children and their spouses, Patricia LaForce and Jack Gibbons, Kailua, Hawaii; James LaForce and Stephen Henderson, New York City; Jane and Anthony Cinquini, Dana Point, Calif.; and one grandchild, Gabriella Cinquini, also of Dana Point. Also surviving are his sister, Alice DeGroot, of Townsend, Wis.; and a brother, Don LaForce, Palos Verdes, Calif.

The family invites friends to celebrate the life of Joe LaForce on Tuesday, April 10 at Oneida Golf and Country Club. A presentation will begin promptly at 3 p.m., followed by a reception. The burial will be in Fort Howard Memorial Park and will be private.

Remembrances can be made to The University of Wisconsin, Green Bay; the Bellin School of Nursing or The Salvation Army. The family kindly requests that no flowers be sent.

Posted April 7, 2007

Smits, Judith Ann

Menasha

On April 4, 2007, at 61, Judy lost her fight with leukemia. Never once did she wonder why God chose her to bear that cross, instead she asked, "Why not me?"

She was born in Iron Mountain, Michigan, to Ray and Jennie Saler. She married and spent 42 wonderful years with her loving husband Ken. Judy is survived by Ken, a son Kevin (Amy), a daughter Kerry (Matt) Lang, and grandchildren: Kassie, Danny, Erin, Collin, Delaney and MacKenzie, brothers: John (Renate) Saler and Robert (Cheryl) Saler and many nieces, nephews, cousins, other relatives, friends and her dog Libby.

Nothing was more important to Judy than her 6 grandchildren. They were the topic of most of her conversations. She kept her lawn chair and bleacher seat in the car so she was ready to attend any activity at any time. For the last few summers, Judy would have "Camp Grandma" sessions out at the lake entertaining the grandkids for hours with silly new games. She absolutely loved it!

Judy was active in sports. An avid golfer, she had quite a knack for the game. She taught her children and grandchildren how to play the game as well. As a member of the Peptoes volleyball team, she went to the Senior Olympics where her team of "old" friends placed 5th nationally. Judy coached and played softball and tennis and was a well-rounded athlete.

She also enjoyed gardening and planted anywhere she could find an open spot of dirt. Each summer, it seemed like a new garden was added somewhere around the yard so she could plant all of the new varieties she would read about. Ken and Judy maintained the flower beds of St. Paul Church for many years. As the season changed, they would head for the warmer climate of Destin, Florida. She was happy to get away from the cold Wisconsin weather and the opportunity to continue her golf game. Judy learned a lot about the Bible with her friends in her Bible study group at Resurrection Catholic Church in Destin.

One of her latest passions was scrap booking. Between their travels and the many sporting events she had ample opportunity to gather new photos. Everywhere she went, her camera was always with her. She loved to take pictures and turn them into beautiful and meaningful scrapbook pages.

Judy's mass of Christian Burial will be 4 p.m. on Monday, April 9, 2007, at ST PAUL CATHOLIC CHURCH, 410 E. Wallace Street, Combined Locks, with Fr. Jim Lucas officiating. Friends will be received at Church on Monday, from 2 p.m. until the time of service. All are welcome to join the family for a dinner following the mass. In lieu of flowers, a memorial is being established in her name. The Boettcher Family Funeral Home, Kaukauna, is assisting the family. 920-766-2099

Stella B. Alberts, 82, De Pere. Stella's greatest desire, to move into her mansion in Heaven and be with her Lord and Saviour, Jesus Christ, was realized on April 5, 2007.

Prior to moving to the Green Bay area she was a resident in Oconto County and enjoyed country living. While there she was a faithful member of the Oconto Gospel Chapel. During her time in Oconto County, and when not helping her husband on the farm, she worked at Kriewaldt Glove Factory, and later as an optometric assistant to Dr. James F. Janda. As retirement progressed she and William moved to Green Bay and became faithful members of Bay City Baptist Church, enjoying the Young at Heart Activities and fellowship of all the friends and members of the church. She enjoyed listening to the preaching of the never-changing Gospel of Jesus Christ. Most recently they have resided at Harbor Suites Assisted Living.

She is survived by her loving and faithful husband of 64 years, William Alberts, De Pere. Stella is also survived by two sons Noel (Deborah) Alberts, Midway, Ark.; Delbert (Beverly) Alberts, Maribel; a daughter, Judi (Russ) Lefevre, Green Bay; 11 grandchildren, Bonnie (Jim) Ridderbush, Reuben Kaye, Bobbie Sue Kaye, Katie Kaye, Richard (Wendy) Alberts, Randy (Cynthia) Alberts, Keith Alberts, Tim (Laura) Alberts, Jamie (Ann) Alberts, Donald Alberts, Sherry La Crosse and Linda La Crosse; 11 great-grandchildren; her nieces, nephews and their families held a special place in her heart, Jan (Darryl) Gertzfield, Carol Crawford, Darlene Crawford, Pat (Bernie) Hallett, Dawn (Stan) Sutherland, Merribeth (George) Dorvick, Alan Crawford, Marlene Hunt, Bill (Nancy) Hunt, Karol Hunt, Kathy (Dave) Winters and "adopted niece" Sandy Sigo.

She was preceded in death by her parents, Ralph and Ethel Crawford; two brothers, Merrill and Carl Crawford; a sister, Mabel Hunt; a sister-in-law, Elizabeth "Beth" Crawford.

The family will receive relatives and friends at the Bay City Baptist Church, 1840 Bond St., Green Bay. from 9 to 11 a.m. Tuesday, April 10, 2007. Funeral services will be held 11 a.m. Tuesday at the church with the Rev. Morris Bender officiating. On line condolences may be expressed at www.gallagherfuneralhome.net.

Special thanks to the care givers that provided her with compassion, comfort and medical direction, Harbor Suites staff, Unity Hospice workers, the 2nd floor nurses and sitters, as well as the doctors at Bellin Hospital.

Posted April 8, 2007

Boice, Jean Fennell

Jean Boice passed away peacefully Sunday, April 1, 2007, at Scandia Village, Sister Bay, Wis. She was born on Aug.17, 1913, in New Rochelle, N.Y., to Edward and Grace (Bowden) Fennell. She graduated from Briarcliff Women's School. In 1937, she married Hugh Kendall Boice Jr. at Quaker Ridge outside of New York City.

Because Hugh was an owner and executive in the radio and television business, the couple moved many times years during the course of their 46 year marriage. In 1947, Jean and Hugh moved to Milwaukee where they raised their two sons. In 1967, they moved to Green Bay. The family first visited Door County in 1953. Hugh and Jean became part- time residents in 1972, when they built a home near Juddville. Jean's ability to adapt, and her enjoyment of others proved that wherever they landed, she garnered friendships that lasted a lifetime.

Called "Birdie" by family and friends, Jean enjoyed the outdoors where she spent her time fishing, hunting, golfing, and bird watching. Her prowess as a cook and hostess was widely known and modeled by many. She had a strong, humble faith and was an active member of the Episcopal Church for most of her life. She had a distinctive affinity with birds, children, and dogs, and has been called an "other mother" by many younger adults who knew her well.

Jean is survived by sons, Hugh Kendall Boice III (Bonnie), Cleveland, Ohio; Edward Petrie Boice, Ellison Bay Wisconsin; and grandson, Orrin Kendall Boice, Los Angeles.

She was preceded in death by her husband; her parents; sister, Grace Curley; brother, Edward Fennell; and niece, Anne Curley Fassett.

Jean's grace, courage, compassion, and cheerfulness will continue to be a model for all she touched. Memorial contributions in her name may be made to Christ the King  Holy Nativity Episcopal Church, Sturgeon Bay, Wis., and Scandia Village Sister Bay, Wis.

A memorial service is planned for August in Door County.

The family extends great appreciation for the kindness of care to Scandia Village, Unity Hospice, Reverend Barbara Sanja, and Casperson Funeral Home.

DeGelleke, Mrs. Armin (Elaine)

Mrs. Armin (Elaine) DeGelleke, 79, Green Bay, died Friday evening, April 6, 2007, following a short illness. Born in Green Bay on July 25, 1927, she is the daughter of the late Jacques and Leola (La Plante) Ferrier. Elaine married Armin DeGelleke on June 18, 1949, at Siloah Lutheran Church in Milwaukee. Elaine dedicated her life to raising her family. She was a member of the Red Hat Club and enjoyed gardening, crafts, her pets, nature, sunsets on the bay, and trips through the neighborhood on the ATV with Armin.

Survived by her beloved husband, Armin; two daughters, Carol VanDenack, Denise (Brian) Bosar, all of Green Bay; three grandchildren, Robert VanDenack, Christina VanDenack, and Nicole Bosar all of Green Bay; five great-grandchildren; special cousin, Leverette Paul, Luxemburg; sister-in-law, Burnell Schroeder, Slinger, Wis.

Friends may call at MALCORE (EAST) Funeral Home, 701 N. Baird Street, from 4 to 8 p.m. Monday and prior to the funeral on Tuesday. Tuesday visitation will continue at the funeral home prior to the funeral. Funeral Tuesday 10 a.m. at the funeral home with Pastor Michael Baucom. To send an online condolence, visit malcorefuneralhome.com.

Posted April 8, 2007

Martens, Lynne Marie (Schneider) March 11, 1966  March 28, 2007

After a long fight with cancer, Lynne passed away Wednesday at home in Granite Bay, Calif., surrounded by her husband Dean and family. She was born in Green Bay, Wis., to Alvin and Jean (Balza) Schneider. Lynne and Dean were married May 30, 1987 at St. Josephs Chapel in Green Bay. She graduated from Southwest High school in 1984 and attended the University of Wisconsin { Oshkosh. After graduating she worked for Tully Health Systems in Appleton and Bemis Manufacturing in Sheboygan. They moved to Granite Bay, Calif., in September 1997. She worked for International Business Systems in Folsom as a computer programmer and team leader. She was a kind, loving, accepting person with a magnetic personality.

Lynne is survived by her husband Dean; her mother, Jean Schneider, Green Bay; three brothers, Donn and Liza, Green Bay; Gregg and Susan, Morrisville, N.C.; and Todd and Deb, Coon Rapids, Minn.; and one sister, Kaye and Clarence Campbell, Ashland Wis.; nieces, nephews and in-laws.

She was preceded in death by her father, Alvin W. Schneider.

A Celebration of Life will be held at St. Agnes Church, 1484 Ninth Street, Green Bay, on Saturday, April 14 at 1 p.m. Visitation will be at the church from 12 to 1 p.m. Business casual dress requested.

Please donate to the American Cancer Society in lieu of flowers.

Posted April 8, 2007

Ness, Paul E.

Paul E. Ness, 61, Green Bay, passed away Friday, April 6, 2007, at a local hospital. Paul was born March 20, 1946, in Green Bay, a son of Elmer and Lena (Dorn) Ness. He graduated from East De Pere High School in 1964, and then served his country from 1965 to 1968 in the Army. After his service Paul worked for Procter & Gamble for 26 years. On June 27, 1970, Paul married the former Sharon Smits. He then spent his time as an owner/operator semitruck driver. He then worked for J& A Quick Lube.

Paul was a fan of NASCAR, trips to Shawano raceway with Pauly, country music, trips to Jacksonville to visit Lee and Linda, and Georgia to visit Sue and Terry Tubbs, fishing at the cabin, cookouts with family, anything mechanical with his hands to work on, reminiscing of childhood, and handyness of building trailers.

Paul is survived by his wife Sharon; children, Tammy (David Bosetski) Ness, Barbara (Lonnie Block) Ness, Travis (Margo) Schenkus, Cindy (Steve Marvin) Ness, and Crystal (Jason Krueger) Ness; grandchildren, Michael Ness, Tyler Daniels, and McKenzie and McKayla Humblet; his special friend, Sissy. Paul is further survived by his siblings, Marlene Ness, Lee (Linda) Ness, Jerry Ness, Charlotte Schenkus, and Diane Amenson; mother-in-law, Delores Smits; brother-in-law, Cletus Daul; other brothers and sisters-in-law; and aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins, and friends.

Paul is preceded in death by his parents; sister, Janice Daul; father-in-law, Elmer Smits; brothers-in-law, Tony Smits, Pinger Smits, and Dick Smits; and a special friend, Bumper.

Visitation for Paul will be held Tuesday, April 10, 2007, from 3 to 7 p.m. at RYAN FUNERAL HOME, 305 N. 10th St, De Pere. Funeral service for Paul will be at 7 p.m. with Pastor Speckhard officiating. Burial will be in Hillside Cemetery, Chilton. Please visit www.ryanfh.com to send online condolences to the Ness family.

The Ness family would like to thank VA Hospital, Madison; VA Hospital, Nashville; Dr. Calendar, Dr. Winkler, Green Bay Oncology, St Vincent 9th Floor staff, St. Vincent Dialysis, and friends at Grama's Diner.

Although we now pay our last Earthly respects to Paul today, we shall always greatly treasure his unique character as one of a very special kind. We shall all deeply remember Paul's funny jokes and constant strength to fight off life's ever endless battle.Our memories shall always recall Paul's tender kindness that no one else could ever bring us except Paul himself. We shall all remember Paul's great interest in working and solving of crossword puzzles that really captured his interest beyond compare. We now sense the great loss of Paul's very loving family and give thanks for the time that God Almighty has allowed him to be a husband and precious father.Although we share our great sorrows today, our golden memories will become our true treasures that shall strongly remain with us forever. Today we all speak our most meaningful prayers and shed our sad tears until that day when we meet again along Heaven's celestial shore.
